div.p: At Moses's desire I inclose his bill. he says it may appear large: but hopes when You see his work, it will not appear extravagant. I will pay him all or part as you direct.

I am but in poor spirits by the loss of my friends, since I wrote last. Tom Hunt a true & constant friend of forty years standing went off rather suddenly three weeks ago. yesterday I heard of the death of Mr Hson another respected friend.This friend, probably of the name of Hudson, has not been identified. London goes more & more empty to me every time I visit it. my own turn ought to be thought of!

In the neighborhood of Wynnstay where I have lately been I heard of a sad reverse in that luxurious house the family reduced to two maid servts in the house: & two laborers in the grounds & gardens.On financial difficulties at Wynnstay in 1787, see 1088. The very hops & poultry sold: even to a single Pheasent & single Guinea hen. Mr H I dare say died very rich. he lived handsomely but with great prudence. his family will demand some of his wealth for he left I think twelve children.

closer.salute:
I conclude with my best wishes & assurances of being
Dear Sir
Yraffect friend
